top_comment.text:
BABYSITTING TIPS: 
1. Be fun! : if you are fun and cheerful with the child than they will beg 
their parents to hire you again! 
2. Know where everything is. : if an emergency happens you need to know 
where all the supplies are.
3. MEAN IT. : if a child is being bad you CAN'T say something like "if you 
do that one more time I'm going to take away ALL your toys" because the 
child knows you don't really mean what you're saying. You SHOULD say 
something like " stop acting like that right now or I will put you in time 
out."
4. Get to know the kids. : if you know the kid(s) it will make them feel 
more welcome and closer to you. You can ask them things like "do you have 
any hobbies?" "What's your favorite T.V show?" This way you will know the 
child(ren) better. 

I hope that helped!﻿
top_comment.author: Barbie Lover

approximately  $12 an hour...
Ex.

Is this too much money?

they give me HUGE tips every time!

Please answer this girls....﻿

Take an old perfume bottle or spray bottle, put a lable that says monster 
spray on it. If the child is afraid of monsters. Spray around his room and 
house. If he or she can't sleep, say it is sleep spray.﻿
top_comment.author: lauren mccue

comments.text:
+tmwalkerm You give a good point but one part of growing up is 
understanding the difference between good and bad. The monster spray is 
good, non-toxic and safe, while your new ant repellent is bad, poisonous, 
and harmful. An older child should be alert of the chemicals, so a parent 
of a younger child, toddler or infant should be able to keep the chemicals 
out of reach.

top_comment.text:
Hey brooklyn and bailey! During the summer I babysit a girl who's four. The 
problem is that she always says "no." Its basically her way or the highway. 
She gets extremely angry if her little brother who's two or her baby sister 
who's one tries to touch her. Its almost impossible to play with all 3 of 
them to begin with. PLUS the fact that she only does what she wants and she 
won't listen. Anybody help? Please!!!﻿
top_comment.author: Madison Parent

comments.text:
+Madison Parent Give her a firm warning. If she does it again, put her in 
time-out for 4 minutes (1 minute per year of age). If she gets up before 4 
minutes are up, put her right back in time-out and start the time over. 
Don't talk, just put her back. When she sits for the entire 4 minutes, go 
to her, explain what she did wrong, and have her apologize. When she does, 
ask for a hug and let her go on her way.If she refuses to apologize, re-set 
the timer for another 4 minutes and go back and ask for an apology again. 
Trust me, it works and she will learn to behave and she'll respect you for 
enforcing the rules and having a backbone (: Oh, and if you think it 
doesn't work, watch Supernanny. I've learned how to make kids behave from 
watching her. She's amazing and knows what she's doing. She's taught me 
everything I know (:
comments.author: StarsomeGirl

comments.text: Try to talk to her parents about it, and maybe be more firm ;)
comments.author: Laura Fillmore

top_comment.text:
But what would you do if when the parents leave and the child starts to cry 
their eyes out!!!!!!!﻿
top_comment.author: Allie Ross

comments.text:
+Allie Ross Just keep calm and distract them. Give them their favorite toy 
or put their favorite song on. Or just console them. I babysat a 1 year old 
little boy and he'd cry for a little while and I just held and hugged him 
and he was fine after a minute or two. Distraction is key though (: 
Distract and console is what I do and it works. They don't stay upset for 
long. In a daycare I worked at, one of the other workers had a 3 year old 
and he'd cry FOREVER. It was so bad that she put him in timeout and 
wouldn't let him out of timeout until he stopped crying. It sounds really 
harsh but it actually worked! Pretty soon, he stopped crying when his 
mother dropped him off. I don't know that I would do that...only if it was 
really bad like this little boy. He would seriously cry for a good hour or 
more at first.
comments.author: StarsomeGirl

comments.text:
i just took the babysitting class today at Hospital near me. it tells you 
that before the parents leave take the child(ren) to another room and play 
with them and it helps alot.

This Friday is my first time babysitting!! I'm so nervous! Any tips? 7 year 
old girl and 4 year old by!!??﻿
top_comment.author: Username2001

comments.text:
it's easy. 1st get to know them. sit down at their eye level - and ask 
their favourite colours, favourite subject in school, if they ahve a 
favourite friend at school [favourites are safe conversations that keep 
kids positive].  if you're babysitting in the evening, play calm games [no 
tag, no 'you're it' games, it will excite them too much and make ti 
difficult to calm down for bed time.] acknowledgement is great for these 
ages. anything they do that is kind for you or for each other, acknowledge 
it. bring out the best in them.  play 'i spy' games by colour, by sound, by 
shape. good luck!
comments.author: Jennifer Devine

top_comment.author: Erica Alamanjo

comments.text:
+Erica Alamanjo Yeah, you have to do what works for you (: I tried 
babysitting in my house and having the mom bring toys for the kids...and my 
dogs kept chewing on them, lol. I'm older and lucky my mom lets me use her 
car (:
comments.author: StarsomeGirl

comments.text:
+StarsomeGirl True, however I can't drive and my mom has her own job and 
isn't willing to just drive me to anyone's house so we made a deal. I could 
start babysitting, but the kids comee to our house which I was fine with. I 
don't watch really young kids their usually around my brothers age so the 
kids could play with his stuff and bring theirs. I usually have them just 
coloring, drawing, or watching tv, but not too much to XD. The only thing i 
have to lock up is cabnit doors and whatnot dont want them going threw 
stuff.
comments.author: Erica Alamanjo

comments.text:
+Erica Alamanjo Most parents (where I live) want to bring their kids to my 
house. I don't like when parents want me to babysit in my own home. I like 
going to the parents' houses because that is where the kids are the most 
comfortable, that's where all their toys are and stuff. Plus, if you 
babysit early in the morning, the child can remain sleeping and when it's 
bedtime/naptime, they have their own bed to sleep in. I have to turn down 
babysitting jobs where the parents insist I babysit in my own home (I live 
with my grandma and its too stressful for her) but its also super annoying 
because my house isn't child-proof and it sucks worrying about my things 
getting broken. At least the parents have their house kid-proof, lol
comments.author: StarsomeGirl

Honestly even once you feel ready, it's not really your choice, it's the

drop subtle hints, like ask you questions. How are you with kids? Do you

extracurriculars. Just be honest and mature so they know that you're ready 
and they can trust you.

comments.text: I love you
comments.author: JAVANNA McNiel

top_comment.text:
How old did you start babysitting?? And is it better if you had a friend or 
buddy to partner up with??﻿
top_comment.author: Elaine Walker

comments.text:
I used to babysit with my best friend and it was actually more fun for the 
kids. It was perfect because we were babysitting twins and one of them 
liked me and one of them liked my friend! We had so much fun that the girls 
asked their dad if we could babysit them again! We were their babysitters 
for about two years actually.so yeah, you can do it with a buddy as long as 
you still keep an eye on the kids.
comments.author: Barbie Lover

comments.text:
sometimes it isnt better to have a friend or buddy with unless you are both 
serious. the parents might think you will goof around a lot.
comments.author: MissKeiLimePie

top_comment.text: How old of kid do you babysit.﻿
top_comment.author: lily zhao

comments.text:
It depends on how old you are. For a younger babysitters like me (I am a 
mature 11 year old) I would say a kid who is 4 years-6 years. But for 
someone older and more advanced in babysitting they can have children 6 
months- 8 years. I hope that helped a little.
comments.author: Barbie Lover

comments.text: They started when they were 11
comments.author: srishti Singh

top_comment.text: Are brooklyn and bailey sisters﻿
top_comment.author: Michelle Davis

comments.text: Yea. They are twins.
comments.author: Alex Spongy

top_comment.text:
I'm 11 but I'm Australian, could I still baby sit or would I have to be 
older?﻿
top_comment.author: Shaza shay

comments.text:
I also feel that not only are 11 year olds are too young to babysit, they 
should have babysitters at that age.
comments.author: Sydney Henderson

comments.text: You can only start babysitting when you're 16 in Australia
comments.author: Karrie Chua

comments.text:
if you feel confident i would go for it! just make sure its nothing that 
you can't handle. ask your mom how she feels about it also. its also a good 
idea to just start out by babysitting neighbors or kids you already know. 
good luck!
comments.author: Chloe O

comments.text:
Well i do stay at home by my self if my mum needs to go somewhere quickly, 
but if she takes longer than about half an hour she would take me.
comments.author: Shaza shay

comments.text:
I'm 12 and I stay home alone with the kids I babysit. ( 2,3, and 6 years 
old) Then again, the parents do trust me a lot, so get to know the parents 
AND the kids before/during babysitting.
comments.author: Morgan Rackley

comments.text:
it depends how old the kids are and how many there are. you could ask your 
mom or dad to help you out.
comments.author: Chloe O

comments.text:
Age 11 is very young to be babysitting. A good age to start is 15, maybe 
even 14 if you have experience. But age 11 is not old enough to stay home 
alone and care for others. :)
comments.author: Sydney Henderson

comments.text:
If you feel you are mature enough and you have done a baby sitting and cpr 
course. You are ready!
comments.author: Olivia Marshmallow

captions.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]
-Hi, guys.
-Hey, everyone.
We're Brooklyn and Bailey.

And today we've decided to do
Babysitting 101 because we've

been getting lots of babysitting
jobs during the summer.

And it is very important
to do your best

when you're babysitting
because then the parents will

be so happy, they'll
want to hire you again,

and then they'll go tell
all of their friends.
-It's like free marketing.
-Honestly, it is.

-Free marketing for your
own little business.
It's so cool.
-OK.

So first off, you'll want to go
to one of your local community
centers or hospitals.

And they have a class you can
take that shows you and teaches

you how to do CPR, in
case one of the kids

gets in an emergency
and they need it.

And after you do
that class and you

learn how to do all
of the medical things,

you should have your parents
spread the word that you're

ready and want jobs
for babysitting.

-So once your parents
have spread the word

and you finally get
a babysitting job,

it's very important that you
ask the questions, like, what's

their schedule, what's
their bedtime routine, what

do they eat, are
there any allergies?

-It makes you seem like
a responsible, interested
babysitter.

And it makes the parents
like you more because you're

on the ball and
you know what all

of the kid's needs
and wants are.
So it'd be good.
-Yeah.

So it's very important for you
to be the one asking questions.

-So when the parents
leave, try to get

to know the kids-- like
their ages, their names--

so they feel more
comfortable around you.

And be their friend, be
cheerful, make them happy,

do something funny,
so they feel like they
can get to know you better.

-But also make sure that they
know that you mean business.

-So you're not all fun
and games and no business.

Be fun and games and
business, so that it's like--
-You're in between.
-It's a double package.
-Double for one.

-So here are some
things you definitely

do not want to do while
you're babysitting.

-Turn the TV on because
it distracts you

from watching the kids,
and then the kids are not

doing anything active-- they're
just sitting on the couch.
-Yeah.

Another thing is you do not
want to have guests over.

No family, no friends, no
boyfriends or girlfriends.
None of that.

-Nothing that will distract
you from watching the kids.
-Mhm.

-And also, no long phone
calls or texting your friends

while you're babysitting
because that also distracts you
from actually babysitting.
-Mhm.

-You also want to
stay home, preferably.

If you have a car, preferably,
stay in the house or the house
premises, like the backyard.

-Yeah, because if you go out
on long walks to the park,

that's fun for the kids but
it also invites accidents,

and it's kind of hard to
keep all of the kids wrangled

together when
you're at the park.

And another major
don't is do not snoop.
Do not snoop.
Do not try on clothes.

Do not ruffle through
their personal items.

-Because you are an invited
guest in their house,

and you should not
be the one looking

through all of
their private stuff.
-You have no rights to do that.

Some things to do, while
you're babysitting,

are fun activities
with the kids.

You want to interact
with them and give them
some fun active things to do.
-Yeah.

So you can do crafts
or play games,

or if you're with little
girls, you can play dress up
or princess.
-Yeah.

And you can download
apps on your phone,

or you can make fun music
videos or just funny videos,
in general.

And you can usually
distract the kids

for like an hour with those--
those fun apps and stuff.
-Mhm.

And some other things to do,
while you're babysitting,

is to certainly pay attention
and to also be kind to the kids

so that they know that
they can trust you.

-And you can periodically
text the parent updates,

like, I just fed
the kids, now we're

going to go play a board
game because lots of parents

usually worry about
what the kids are doing

or how the babysitter is
doing while they're gone

and it's really good for them
to know what you're doing.
-I would worry about my kid.

-And last of all,
you want to clean.
-Clean.

-It's really good
when you clean.

Parents don't usually
feel like they

need to rehire you
when they come home
to a dirty, messy house.
-Yeah.

I once had a
babysitting job, where

the parents had just--
they said, oh, it's okay.

When the kids are in bed, you
can just sit around and relax.

But I saw that the house needed
a little bit of cleaning.

And so I went ahead
and vacuumed the floor

and put the dishes
in the dishwasher.

And when they got home,
they were so happy,
they paid me extra.

So cleaning is very important
when you're babysitting.
-Yeah.

And I had an experience
like that, one time.

And they actually
called my mom, the day

after, and were raving
about how awesome it

was to find you were a
babysitter that cleaned up

their house without them
having to ask them to do it.

And it's just a really good
thing to get you rehired.

And it makes the parents
like you a lot more.

And then they go tell their
other friends about you.

And it's the free
marketing again.
Yay.

-So when bedtime rolls around,
if the parents give you

a specific time to
put the kids to bed,

you need to put them
to bed at that time.
-Yeah.

-And if you have a kid that's
having a hard time going

to bed, there are things you
can do, like read them a story.
-Read them books.
I mean, you can sing them songs.

I sing them lots of
fun songs, sometimes.

-And if the kid's
having more trouble,

after you've tried everything,
you can text the parents

and ask them what they
do with their kids.
-Mhm.

And just try to keep them--
try to calm them down,

so they feel like
they can go to sleep.
OK.

So when the parents
come home, give them

an honest report about what
happened when they were gone.

And be like, your kids are so
adorable, we had so much fun,

we made this video--
here, watch it--

so they know that you had
a good time with their kids
and you interacted with them.

And if you did have trouble
putting one of the kids to bed,

just tell them that
you had trouble.

And be like, what can I
do better next time, when

you call them-- or call me-- so
that you can fix it, next time.

And then the kid
will go to bed easy.
-Yeah.

Every parent wants to
see their babysitter

and see that they're as
involved as they would have been

or that they care for their
kids as much as they do.

So the big question that we
know you've been asking is,

how much do we charge
for babysitting?

And it honestly
depends on the family.

Generally, you don't want to
be the one to bring up money.

You want the parents to
be the one to bring it up.

And if they give you a price,
and you think it's reasonable,
then go ahead with it.

But if they ask you
now, what do you usually

get paid for babysitting,
our general idea is--

-If they have three kids and
under, just say, $4 to $5
an hour.

And if they have three
kids and above, say,

it's usually $1 an
hour and $1 per kid.

So that's our general
consensus for money,
but not everyone has to do that.
-Yeah.

Honestly, just make sure that
you do the best that you can

and have it be as
much fun for the kids

and make sure that you
leave the house cleaner
than when you came.

Your goal is to have either them
texting your parents about what

a great babysitting you
are or have their kids

telling their parents,
wow, we had so much fun
with this babysitter.
Bring her again.
We had so much fun.
-I want her to come again.

-That is like your
bottom line goal.
You want that.
OK.
We're going to LA this weekend.

And we're so excited to meet
all of you guys at VidCon.

And while we're
down there, we're

having a meet and
greet on Saturday.

We're actually having
two meet and greets.

And you can get
the details below.
-Mhm.

-Be sure to check us out on
Twitter, @brookeandbailey.
And we'll see you next week.
-Bye.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

(SINGING) Say it like
you know it's true.

Only you can decide
if you'll see this

through because you
can do anything.
Yeah, you can do anything.
-[INAUDIBLE].
[MUSIC PLAYING]

title: Babysitting 101 | Tips and Guidelines for Beginners
